text: Bottle at home. Pours gloopy jet black with a thick tan head. Aromas of dark chocolate, leather, charcoal, wood. Taste is rich, light sweet, good roasted, tarry bitter. Long bitter finish. Oily texture. Good stuff.

33cl bottle. BBE 03/10/14. Enjoyed on 15.10.2014. Pours pitch black with ash-brown head. Aroma of ash, roasted malts, black pepper and chocolate. A true stout sensation. Everything is present here what you would expect from stout - iron, caramel, chocolate, cloves and some ginger. Smoke and oak bark in the aftertaste. Not as thick as you would expect. Slightly oily and slick - goes very smoothly down the throat. Soft carbonation, that is not sufficient to keep the head on for longer than 10 minutes (this is not a bad thing at all). Long and smokey finish. Alcohol is not noticeable at all. I would not hesitate to sample that. Says that it is good for aging also.

330ml bottle, pours black with a tan head, chocolate malt in the aroma, oatmeal, roasty, vanilla ice cream. Nice balance with an abrupt dry bitter finish. light sweetness, medium bitterness, full body, creamy, soft carbonation,.
Bottle at home. Rich roasty aroma. Taste is dark chocolate, strong espresso, licorice. Slightly earthy. Pretty amazing.

33 cl. bottle sampled @ Bierfestival Mechelen 2014. Oily black, little mocha bubbles. Nose is thick liquorish, not very outspoken, syrupy fudge, chocolate. Taste is not very outspoken either, roast, liquorish, syrup, chocolate, coffee, light herbal, touch varnish. Thick syrupy body. Okay but not very outspoken, decent. I mean that, it is decent on its own but pales in comparison to the rest within the style.

Bottle (take away from the Drunken Duck); pours a very dark brown with dark beige head; has a roasted malt aroma with coffee and chocolate notes; has a strong roasted malt taste with chocolate, coffee, and alcohol; finish bitter coffee; good stout

Good fulsome stout. Deep black with lasting beige head. Roasted malt aroma. Some fruit - raspberry? - pokes through the bitter dark chocolate and treacle taste. Full bodied - more creamy than oily. Another good one from Buxton.

330 ml bottle from Birra+ (Bottled on 09-06-2014). Pitch black, dark and thick like used motor oil, with a small, creamy, moderately persistent light brown head. Lovely roasted and toasted smell, lots of bitter dark chocolate notes, some light vanilla and licorice presence, fudge and toffee candy, no alchool at all on the nose. Slightly warming, slick and velvety, slightly fruity (darker berries types), pleasent but mild bitterness. Extremely easy to drink for the ABV. Slightly ashy, roasted and chocolaty aftertaste. Bring out the Buxton. Christmas present off the missus. Filthy pitch with a loose tan head that sticks around. I¬ím talking entirely about the beer here. Soap and blueberry-forward nose with saline, soft lactic, prune, iodine, peaty malt and roasted pepper suggestions. Huge bodied, imperial soft, bittersweet and mellow with cocoa, tobacco and pepper notes. The cheeky hops suggested by the nose don¬ít really emerge. Dry and chalky like high cocoa chocolate. Bit one-dimensional and Baltic for me. But good.

Bottle from Cotteridge Wines, Birmingham. Poured flat which lowered my expectations. I needn¬ít have worried. This was delicious - crisp roastiness, with a smooth bodied warming capacity. Went down einen treat. I trust Buxton.

Bottle from Mikkeller&Friends bottle shop. Black beer with a decent beige head. Roasted chocolate aroma, caramel, cocoa powder, cream notes, licorice, vanilla, raisins, figs, toffee, vinous notes. Fig and raisin flavor, caramel, roasted, vanilla, chocolate, cocoa powder, coffee, licorice, vanilla, toffee notes, tar notes. Smooth full bodied and really tasty. Roasted dark chocolate finish with licorice, raisins and salty notes.

Black no head. Strong coffee roasted malty notes. No carbonation! Heavy smooth creamy texture. Need more and lace for my taste.

Bottle at Pigs Ear 2013. Intense black beer thick and unctuous. Lasting tan head. Thick choc aroma. Smells and tastes like an imperial stout. Tar flavour. Not much hop. Some soy sauce. Good tasty beer. Good balance. Choc coffee. Some dryness. Ok.

Bottle 330ml.Clear dark black colour with a small to average, fizzy, virtually none lacing, fully diminishing, light brown head. Aroma is moderate to heavy malty, roasted, burnt, chocolate, dark chocolate, alcohol, ash notes, wood notes, smoke notes. Flavour is moderate to heavy sweet and bitter with a long duration, tart roasted, burnt, dark roasted, dry. Body is medium to full, texture is creamy, carbonation is soft to flat, finish feel is light alcoholic. [20131012]

A black beer with a weak and brown head that is one of the darkest head that I have seen. The nose is strongly roasted with coffee, luckily sweetness of dark fruits balancing the roastiness, some liquirice and red berries. Intensive aroma. Taste is almost burned with coffee, almost too burned, some sweetness and dark fruits, herbal hops. Medium+ bodied, low carbonation, quite smooth. The strongly roasted and straightforward beer.
Bottle. Black with virtually no head. Powerful and slightly dry. A very pleasant and strong stout. Worth trying.

330 ml bottle.
Pours a black colour with a minimal beige head. Aroma of roasted malts, peppery spiciness and some soy sauce. Flavour is very roasty and burnt with malts, bitter chocolate, strong bitterness, ash and espresso. Medium bodied, oily mouthfeel and a mouthdrying, bitter, ash finish. Very straightforward in it¬ís roastiness.

Bottle picked up from ¬íJacks¬í, Westholme Stores, Goring-on-Thames, Oxon 20th November 2013 consumed at home Thursday 28th November 2013   Black as deep space, really, really black with a tan head. Roasty, malty with some liquorice, very thick in mouth, tarry, like licking the tar off of a melting asphalt road. It¬ís oily, thick in the mouth and roasty & bitter. There is a citrussy edge, its good.  A7 A4 T8 P4 Ov15 3.8

Bottle from Beer Hive, Edinburgh [241113]
Pich black, thin dirty tan bubbly rim round glass
Aroma - rich deep dark malts, deep roast, some soy, dab of burnt wood, bit tarry, quite complex
Taste - Big roasted malts, burnt wood, bitter dark chocolate, rich dark malts, some bitter hops in there, tar, some coffee grounds, complex 
Palate - Soft carb, medium to full body, bitter roast but some dark sweet malts keep it in check, quite bitter overall, rich smooth roast. Finish as main flavour, long lingering considerably bitter roast with dark tarry malts, some more bitter hops coming thorough here but too over bitter in the finish 
Overall - Drinks with a complexity found in imperial stouts around 9-10%. Good stuff.

UPDATED: JAN 5, 2014 Bottle. Pours black as oil and looks as viscous. No head at all really. Some large, mocha-colored bubbles on the sides. In the beginning the aroma is a lot of cocoa and by lot I mean a lot. It overpowers everything else. Maybe some roast, a tad of liquorice. But really, not much else besides the cocoa. Later on the liquorice and roast get stronger. After the aroma the taste is a surprise. A lot of roast and coffee, some liquorice, rather dry. A bit of hops in the finish: Grapefruit, citrus, a tad of wood. No cocoa or chocolate in sight. No carbonation at all really, maybe a little bit. Should have more definitely. Feels oily.

330ml bottle from The Beerhive. 
Very think dark tan head with a little lacing. Body is pretty much black. Excellent treacly nose. Flavour of coffee, molasses, burnt sugar. Bitter finish. Big mouthfeel, no carbonation, nice bit of chew. Goes down very well.

Bottled. A pitch black beer with a thin brown head. The aroma has notes of soy sauce, ash, alcohol, and roasted malt. The flavor is sweet with notes of roasted malt, ash, alcohol, and dark bitter chocolate, leading to a bitter finish.

UPDATED: SEP 22, 2014 Bottle: Nose is hazelnut, lactose, leaves, a little chocolate, all very rich and full. Taste is smoke, licorice, hazelnut, espresso, roast, wood. Long finish. Mouthfeel is slippery. Very nice.

Bottle from The Beer Parlour, Chesterfield. Looks like melted chocolate when pouring. Darkest chestnut brown. Thin, tan head. Aroma of dark chocolate. Some morello cherry liquour. Very boozy. Taste is an instant demerara sweetness that rapidly gives way to a quite astringent, red fruit dryness. Very tasty beer.

Bottle from Vino Wines. Impenetrable black body with a thin tan head that gradually fades. Light lacing. Aroma of Twiglets, pepper and charred wood. Strong flavour of Twiglets, spice, Marmite, coffee and chocolate. Medium body with a smooth, silky mouthfeel. Very soft carbonation. A strong, peppery Stout.

33 cL bottle. Pours pitch black with a small tan head. Aroma is roasted malty and chocolate. Light tarish. Thick malty, tarish and dark roasted. Liqourice and dry. Tarish and roasted finish. More a Baltic porter than a stout.
Bottle @ fonefan tasting. Black with a dark brown head. Aroma is sweet, roasted malt, chocolate and coffee. Flavor is medium sweet and rather bitter. Dry and roasted moderate bitter finish. 121013

Bottle, 7.4%. Almost black with small brown head. Aroma is roasted malts, chocolate, coffee, vinous and hop. Flavour is roasted malts, chocolate, coffee, medium sweet, liquorice, hop, vinous, caramel and medium bitter.
Bottle @ fonefan tasting. Nice head with good duration. Color is black. Aroma and taste are bitter hops, roast malt, chocolate, coffee, licorice and has a long dry bitter finish.

Bottle at Euston Tap. It pours . The nose is rich roast, toast, salted liquorice, toffee and coffee. The taste is rich roast, earth, salted caramel, liquorice, decent bitterness, resin charred wood, dark fruitiness, mild acidity and brown sugar with a bitter, toasted finish. Medium+ body and fine carbonation. Rich and flavoursome stuff.
Bottle. Black with little tan head. Meaty aroma, molasses and pine, resinous. Taste of coffee, licorice and resinous pine. Sweet and bitter. Nice.

UPDATED: DEC 23, 2016 Bottle at home 4/10/13 ... deep black .. thin tan head ... soft dry chocolate roast .... dry chocolate roast nose ... deep malts ... heavy roast ... dark malts ... chocolate roast ... big bitter roats malts ... light pine.... meaty but little bitter in linger


Bottle at home 12/16 bottled aug 13...dark black... Small tan head... Soft sweet chocolate roast malts.. Light pine nose... Dry chocolate roast malts... Heavy dry roast... Light bitter chocolate.. Little thin in body.. Almost flat carbonation... Light dry chocolate roast malts.  3.9
330ml bottle. Pours pitch black with a medium head. Aroma is bitter coffee and blackcurrant. Taste has blackcurrant to start with a yeasty, beefy finish. Oily mouthfeel.

Bottle at home.
Pitch black coloured with a small beige head.
Sweet and roasted aroma of caramel, dark chocolate and cookies.
Roasted flavour of caramel, smoke and hops with notes of dark chocolate.
Hoppy and roasted finish.
Bottle at home - thanks to Mette for sharing. Pitch black - white head. Dried fruits, vanilla, cocoa, dark chocolate, some coffee, bitterness, light earthy notes. Nice.

Bottle from Cotteridge Wines; dark brown almost black pour with thin tan head, big roast malt and chocolate aroma, roast malts and chocolate come through in the taste along with bitter expresso coffee, a hint of vanilla and demerera sugar sweetness, along with a viscous mouthfeel, excellent stout, big bold and complex.
